thread.title: Latvian hacker pleads guilty in Manhattan court
thread.title_full: Latvian hacker pleads guilty in Manhattan court - MarketWatch

author: Nicole Hong
title: Latvian hacker pleads guilty in Manhattan court
text:
Shutterstock The Gozi virus is regarded as one of the most destructive ever The Latvian hacker accused of writing malicious computer code to steal millions of dollars from online bank accounts pleaded guilty in Manhattan federal court on Friday.
Deniss Calovskis, 30 years old, allegedly played a major role in distributing the so-called Gozi virus, which law-enforcement officials have described as one of the most financially destructive computer viruses in history. Prosecutors say the virus infected more than one million computers around the world, including ones belonging to the National Aeronautics and Space Administration in the U.S.
On Friday, Calovskis pleaded guilty to one charge--conspiracy to commit computer intrusion--which carries a maximum of 10 years in prison. Under the agreement reached with the government, Calovskis wonâ€™t appeal any sentence that is two years or below.
Calovskis had been facing five criminal charges, including conspiracy to commit bank fraud. The maximum penalty under the original charges would have been 67 years in prison, prosecutors said.
The alleged mastermind behind the virus, Russian national Nikita Kuzmin, pleaded guilty to fraud and computer intrusion charges in 2011 and cooperated with government officials after his arrest in 2010. Prosecutors publicly unsealed the charges against Kuzmin, Calovskis and another co-defendant in 2012.
An expanded version of this report appears at WSJ.com.
